title: Brother or close relative for levirate
vignette: Reuven dies childless leaving a widow. His surviving brother lives abroad but a close cousin is available locally.

options.text: Wait for the brother to perform yibbum or chalitzah.
Let the cousin marry her to keep property in the family.

title: Declining yibbum for personal reasons
vignette: The brother-in-law finds the widow unattractive and prefers not to marry her, though she wants the union.

options.text: Perform chalitzah and let her marry elsewhere.
Proceed with yibbum despite discomfort to uphold tradition.

title: Yibbum vs. existing engagement
vignette: A man engaged to another woman becomes obligated in levirate marriage when his brother dies.

options.text: Break his engagement and fulfill yibbum first.
Proceed with his engagement and perform chalitzah instead.

title: Pregnant widow and uncertain paternity
vignette: A widow is pregnant when her husband dies. It's unclear whether the child will be viable.

options.text: Delay yibbum until after birth to see if a son survives.
Perform chalitzah immediately so she can remarry.

title: Yibbum with partial conversion
vignette: The surviving brother is mid-conversion process and not fully Jewish yet.

options.text: Wait until conversion is complete before deciding.
Let him perform chalitzah now to release the widow.

title: Minor brother's obligation
vignette: The only surviving brother is twelve years old.

options.text: Postpone until he matures even if the widow must wait years.
Allow chalitzah from an adult relative instead.

title: Refusing yibbum to protect inheritance
vignette: The brother fears marrying the widow will split his own estate among her future sons.

options.text: Perform chalitzah to preserve his property.
Proceed with yibbum despite financial loss.

title: Widow engaged to a kohen
vignette: After her husband dies, the widow receives a proposal from a kohen before yibbum occurs.

options.text: Insist on yibbum or chalitzah first.
Permit immediate marriage to the kohen and ignore yibbum.

title: Chalitzah in public vs. private
vignette: The parties prefer to perform chalitzah quietly to avoid embarrassment.

options.text: Allow a private ceremony with minimal witnesses.
Insist on the standard public ritual.

title: Widow refuses both options
vignette: The widow neither wants to marry the brother nor participate in chalitzah.

options.text: Compel her to undergo chalitzah to free her.
Leave her unmarried until she consents.

title: Suspected adulterous widow
vignette: Rumors circulate that the widow had an affair before her husband died.

options.text: Investigate thoroughly and withhold yibbum until cleared.
Ignore unproven gossip and proceed with yibbum.

title: Halitzah shoes unavailable
vignette: The ritual requires a specific leather shoe but none are accessible.

options.text: Delay until a proper shoe is found.
Use a makeshift shoe to avoid prolonging her limbo.

title: Travel costs for yibbum ceremony
vignette: The brother lives overseas and the widow cannot afford the trip for chalitzah.

options.text: Community should fund her travel to fulfill the mitzvah.
Allow proxy chalitzah performed locally.

title: Widow pregnant from another man
vignette: Before yibbum, the widow becomes pregnant through a consensual relationship.

options.text: Require chalitzah only; yibbum is now forbidden.
Permit yibbum anyway to legitimize the child.

title: Multiple brothers â€“ who chooses?
vignette: Three brothers survive; each is eligible for yibbum.

options.text: Let the widow choose which brother performs the rite.
Oldest brother has precedence regardless of her wish.
